questions.question: What is a 'Unit Cell' in a crystalline solid?
options: The smallest repeating structural unit that makes up the crystal lattice
The individual atom at the center of the crystal
A single layer of atoms in a metallic solid
The total volume of the entire crystal
questions.explanation: A crystal is built by repeating the unit cell in three dimensions. Think of it as the 'brick' that builds the 'wall' of the crystal.

questions.question: How many atoms are effectively contained within a single 'Simple Cubic' (Primitive) unit cell?
questions.explanation: In a simple cubic cell, there are atoms at the 8 corners. Each corner atom is shared by 8 adjacent cells, so $8 \cdot (1/8) = 1$ net atom per cell.

questions.question: In a 'Body-Centered Cubic' (BCC) unit cell, where are the atoms located?
options: At the 8 corners and one in the center of the cube
At the 8 corners only
At the 8 corners and the centers of the 6 faces
In a single diagonal line through the cube
questions.explanation: A BCC lattice features one atom at each corner and one full atom resting in the very center of the unit cell.

questions.question: A 'Face-Centered Cubic' (FCC) unit cell contains a total of how many net atoms?
questions.explanation: FCC has 8 corners ($8 \cdot 1/8 = 1$ atom) and 6 faces ($6 \cdot 1/2 = 3$ atoms), totaling 4 atoms per unit cell.

questions.question: The 'Coordination Number' in a crystal lattice refers to:
options: The number of nearest-neighbor atoms touching a central atom
The total number of electrons in the unit cell
The number of unit cells in a gram of the substance
The oxidation state of the metal ion
questions.explanation: Coordination number describes how tightly packed the atoms are; for example, FCC has a coordination number of 12.

questions.question: Which of the following cubic unit cells has the highest 'Packing Efficiency' (the most occupied space)?
options: Face-Centered Cubic (FCC)
Body-Centered Cubic (BCC)
Simple Cubic
They all have the same packing efficiency
questions.explanation: FCC (and Hexagonal Closest Packing) fills approximately 74% of the available volume, the highest possible for uniform spheres.

questions.question: What is the difference between a crystalline solid and an amorphous solid?
options: Crystalline solids have a long-range repeating pattern; amorphous solids do not
Amorphous solids are always colder than crystalline solids
Crystalline solids have no definite melting point
Only amorphous solids contain atoms
questions.explanation: Crystals (like salt or diamond) have orderly lattices, while amorphous solids (like glass or plastic) have disordered, 'frozen' arrangements.

questions.question: An atom located on the FACE of a unit cell is shared between how many individual unit cells?
questions.explanation: An atom on the face is shared by the cell it's in and the one directly adjacent to that face.

questions.question: The 'Lattice Points' in a crystal represent:
options: The positions of the particles (atoms, ions, or molecules) in the structure
The empty spaces between the atoms
The bonds between the atoms
The temperature at which the crystal melts
questions.explanation: Lattice points are the coordinates in space where the constituent particles of the crystal are located.

questions.question: In which cubic system is the edge length ($a$) equal to $2r$ (where $r$ is the radius of the atom)?
options: Simple Cubic
Body-Centered Cubic
Face-Centered Cubic
None of the above
questions.explanation: In a simple cubic cell, atoms at the corners touch along the edge, so the side of the cube is simply two radii ($a = 2r$).
